Looking backwards to that year 2002 when "Furia" was made, one can easily recognize the heralding sings of today's New Generation in Romania. Comedians like Alina Pușcău, a veteran of Romanian Comedy TV or Andreea Bălan and her Cuc Arde In Vara crew were huge successes by that time. They brought all the group into the public's attention and this work still works perfectly in today's climate.

A teen-aged girl gets the horse of her dreams and is trained by an ex-Jockey to participate in London's Grand National Steeplechase. In the course of her progress, various sorts of turmoil in her Dallastown, Pennsylvania, family life are brought to light, including her Dad's drinking and her Mom's neglect in the home. The only family member who gives the girl support is an overly faithful uncle who tries to give her a sense of self

Although there is melodrama at the center or rather at the bottom of this film, the story is told beautifully and subtly and the acting is superb.

For a film about sex and nudity it lacks erotica and perhaps it's this sense of restraint that makes it a very polished and enjoyable film.

Leland follows the story of Leland P. Fitzgerald (Ryan Gosling), a disaffected teenager who has apparently murdered a severely retarded peer, the brother of his would-be lover and mentally unstable classmate Laura (Rachel McAdams). This is essentially a story about young love so the focus is definitely on the turmoil and tribulations of complex and often ambiguous relationships. This is a compelling, troubling, and ultimately a poetic film.

A River Runs Through It is based on the true story of two fly fishing brothers, Norman and Paul, (Brad Pitt and Craig Sheffer) whose Reverend father ( Tom Skerritt ) tries to teach them life’s lessons by way of Fly Fishing. Spirit and Chaos is an artistic biopic of Miyazawa Kenji, a Japanese poet and writer who was active in the early 20th century. Love is the message communicated by Miyazawa, and he was also a dedicated artist who did not place his creed before his creativity, and who chose the difficult path of a writer who was concerned with life. The world held in Miyazawa's poems is a world overflowing with diverse emotions and beautiful and terrible images.

This movie is nothing short of a dark, gritty masterpiece. I may be bias, as the Apartheid era is an area I've always felt for South Africa. The problems they have are immense, and only solutions of varying degree are contemplated and implemented. A woman who hates cats (Alice Krige) and her son (Brian Krause) have moved into a small town, and must deal with a mean cat. The townspeople form a posse to destroy the cat, and the cat ends up killing them. Well, until they grow horns and are resurrected to kill. It is a story of cycles and it is acted well, but the film itself is a little plodding. I'm torn, really,
